newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian bond 96/97 tenders may start soon.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian bond 96/97 tenders may start soon.

text.p: The Australian Treasury is expected to start its bond issuance programme for 1996/97 fairly soon following yesterday's budget statement.
"We have been waiting for the budget and all the final numbers, so we have the option of starting our long-term issuance at any time," a Treasury official said.
"It is possible we could start the programme fairly soon," the official told Reuters.
The Australian government's total borrowing programme for 1996/97 is expected to be around A$7.0 billion.

Aggregate Treasury bond issuance was expected to be around A$6.0 to A$7.0 billion in 1996/97, down from A$7.8 billion in 1995/96, providing scope to introduce a new benchmark line and possibly a 2009 maturity.
A Treasury indexed bond issuance programme of around A$500 million to A$1.0 billion is envisaged for 1996/97.
Here too, the Treasury is considering a new benchmark capital-indexed bond and perhaps a 2020 line of stock.
Supply of Treasury adjustable rate bonds is expected to be around A$1.0 billion with the possible extension of the floating-rate curve beyond the present October 2000.

The current practice of holding Treasury bond tenders every four to six weeks would continue, as would the practice of weighting bond issue towards the first half of the financial year, the Treasury added.
